The reality is that there are many alternative mechanisms for generating radioisotopes, which the minister failed to discuss. He did not bring to our attention the very reasonable alternatives that exist and thereby allow an informed public debate to take place about what is our most substantial science expense to date.
The medical alternatives arise from a number of sources. Firstly, one can reasonably import medical radioisotopes. Some 98 per cent of these are used for diagnostic purposes and only two or three per cent are used for therapeutic purposes. So one can look at alternative diagnostic techniques as well.
In the area of medical radioisotopes, a great many countries import their medical radioisotopes. For example, the United States, the United Kingdom and many countries in Europe import a number of radioisotopes. Countries which we would compare ourselves with also use imported radioisotopes. So that is not out of the question, especially when one 
 considers that, during periods when the research reactor is closed for maintenance, Australia imports substantial quantities of radioisotopes mainly from South Africa but also from Canada and the United Kingdom, and those radioisotopes are able to work very effectively in the Australian medical context.
So that alone is not a compelling argument because we also have available to us cyclotron technology. There is a cyclotron in Sydney and a smaller one in Melbourne, and there are plans to build other units at major hospital facilities around the country. They generate a great many of the radioisotopes which are used in medicine. There is some difficulty at the moment in generating molybdenum which is then allowed to decay into technetium, which is one of the favoured medical radioisotopes. But there are alternative strategies under research at the moment in California which would allow the production of molybdenum and technetium from cyclotron technology and not only from a reactor technology.
There are also medical radioisotopes which are produced by cyclotrons but which are not able to be produced by a reactor. So the issue is not clear cut as far as the medical debate is concerned. I think it is unfortunate that the government opted for the emotive medical argument as its first-run argument rather than allowing a more informed public debate about this to take place so people could make a more rational choice as to whether or not the reactor was necessary.
There is also the question of the scientific and industrial uses of the reactor. For science, reactors are very helpful. There is no doubt that a reactor is useful for the pursuit of some areas of nuclear science. I think ANSTO has done an excellent job in recent years in ensuring that Australia was well represented in those areas. I do not discount the value of that in any way.
Of course, science can be done in a number of ways. There are particle accelerators which use electricity to accelerate particles rather than using the flux of a neutron reactor. There are other mechanisms by which one can undertake studies of materials, for example, spallation sources. Spallation technology is well established. Although that is also expensive and produces some radioactive waste, it is nothing on the scale of a new nuclear reactor. Again even in the scientific area and with the industrial questions of material science, there are a number of alternatives available. They also have not been properly assessed in a wide-ranging public debate.
While the opposition does not per se oppose a new nuclear reactor in this country, it may well be that there are arguments to be made in favour of that. ANSTO is a very creditable and reputable organisation. Their view must be taken with all due weight and significance. Of course, they do have a vested interest in pursuing a new reactor. That obviously is their raison d'etre—the whole reason for the existence of ANSTO—and they would therefore be expected to pursue that argument as strongly as they could in the public arena.
There is also the question of location. The reactor was in an isolated area of Sydney when it was first built, but housing has moved much closer to the reactor and Lucas Heights is now very much a part of suburban Sydney. There is obviously a great deal of disquiet in the area about the prospect of a new reactor and a further 50 years of a nuclear source in the middle of suburban Sydney.
The opposition is very much opposed to the question of building a new reactor in suburban Sydney. While we remain open about the issue of a new reactor in Australia—there are obviously arguments to be had on the science, the industry, the environment, the medical front; 
 all of those things must be properly discussed—we take the view that Lucas Heights is an inappropriate location for this facility. So while we are yet to be convinced by the public argument in relation to the reactor, we do not believe that Lucas Heights is an appropriate venue for it.
The government have failed ANSTO and have failed scientists in this country by not putting the arguments about the need for a new reactor more fairly in the public arena. They have not advanced those arguments in the way that they should have done. They have relied entirely on the emotional impact of the medical question, without ensuring that the public were able to take a more reasoned view. Many scientists support the new reactor but many also question it from the point of view of necessity.
There is the issue of the $300 million initial capital cost. That is a very large amount of money to spend on science and there are many other alternative scientific proposals which could have been funded by that $300 million. No priority analysis appears to have taken place. The government has not set one against the other in the public arena and allowed science and the public to debate which of the alternatives is to be preferred.
The other issue that remains is: where is the $300 million coming from? If one looks at the budget documents presented the other night, one sees that the ANSTO figure is gradually rising. Of course their figure without the reactor is actually suffering a decline, but with the reactor included their funding is rising quite dramatically. The ARC funding—which is a very important source of funding for grants to our young people, to universities, for researchers to undertake further important studies in science—is declining in the forward estimates.
ANSTO strongly put the point of view, which they say is backed by the ARC themselves, that the funding for the reactor has not come from that declining ARC grant. However, on the face of it, on the budget record itself, the government talks about the decline in ARC funding and the figures reflect a very substantial decline. In the absence of any other evidence it is reasonable for scientists and certainly for the opposition to examine the point of view that the government is funding the reactor by a declining grant to ARC.
If that is the case, it will severely impede Australian science in the years ahead and severely disadvantage our young researchers, who already have very little chance of getting an ARC grant. Only about 19 per cent of applicants for ARC grants are successful, and that means some 80 per cent are not. Under the declining allocations listed in the forward estimates, even fewer people will be successful in obtaining those grants. That is a tragedy for our scientists. It is certainly a tragedy for our young scientists, who will increasingly be forced to go offshore.
If this is not the case, if the government in fact has plans to increase ARC funding but they are plans which are not contained in the forward estimates, then the government should make that clear, and they should make it clear immediately. Otherwise, people will draw the conclusion that the declining ARC grant is funding the rising ANSTO grant and that scientists are funding the new reactor from their otherwise expected grants. ANSTO strongly dispute that. I understand that the ARC take a different position, but this is a government which is strongly motivated by the budget dollar.
The Treasurer (Mr Costello) constantly emphasises his ability to effect savings in the Australian government's operation. He constantly emphasises the need for an economic rationalist outcome. While we have had disputes in the parliament between opposition and government about the validity of the Treasurer's strategies, certainly one can understand that 
 the government might well take a decision to reduce one source of funding within a portfolio so that it could increase another. We understand that often ministers are told, `This is a zero sum game. If you want new expenditure, you must come up with savings.' That is a line which the government frequently uses.
Therefore, it is all too easy to draw the conclusion that this has been put to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) and that he has taken a decision to trade off ARC funding against ANSTO funding. If that is not the case, it is up to the minister to come forward quickly in the parliament and in the public arena to dispute that finding; otherwise the opposition and the public will be able to draw that conclusion very reasonably from the budget documents themselves.
In conclusion, while the opposition acknowledges the fine work of ANSTO over the years and accepts that there may well be a role for a research reactor in Australia's future, we believe that that case has not been properly put by the government and that the government has failed to support ANSTO in the way that it should by ensuring that that debate is had on an informed basis.
We certainly believe, though, that Lucas Heights is an inappropriate venue for a nuclear facility, given its location now as part of suburban Sydney. So we want to see a properly informed public debate take place about the need for a reactor as against the other priorities in science and as against the other alternatives in medicine, in industry and in the environmental studies which ANSTO now does. We believe that the government has not taken that view; it has traded off ARC funding against ANSTO funding. We look forward to a more informed public debate on this. I just suspect the government is not going to allow the public that luxury.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Johnston, Ricky, MP
text:
—The object of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998  is to protect the health and safety of people, as well as the environment, from the harmful effect of radiation. As an extreme example of the harm radiation poses for our world, I need only refer to the tragedy that was, and still is, Chernobyl. Today, the after-effects of that dreadful event have still not been measured, nor understood in full. Exposure to high levels of radiation results in horrific sickness and destruction of human beings, as well as our environment.
In the fast changing world that we live in, the usage of radiation in the home and the workplace is becoming more and more common. It is therefore important that, at all times, the health of our people and our country be protected. This is precisely what this bill will do, especially as the Commonwealth, together with the states and territories, will establish uniform radiation controls. The specific purpose of the  Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998  is to provide a regime to regulate the operation of nuclear installations and the management of radiation sources, including ionising materials and both ionising and non-ionising apparatus, where these activities are undertaken by the Commonwealth.
Radiation can cause severe damage to humans and to the environment, yet radiation is also an invaluable tool in many areas of medicine, archaeology and the construction industry. It is used in the food industry and in scientific research and defence. There are many workers, including those in Commonwealth departments such as Customs and in Australia Post and Telstra, who in carrying out their daily work may come in contact with radiation. Many conflicting views on whether there is a safe level of exposure to ionising radiation have been stated. A report from the OECD notes:
There is a threshold level of radiation exposure (or dose) below which no acute damage is observed. However, there is now a substantial body of evidence which shows that cancers can be caused by radiation even at dose levels that are below this threshold. There is no evidence of inherited damage in humans at any dose level, but the fact that such damage is found to occur in other life forms suggests that it could also occur in humans . . . the assumption that a dose, however small, carries with it an element of risk has become a key concept in radiation protection.
Yet this assertion is not necessarily supported by other reports. The United Nations environment program report Radiation doses, effects, risks  states exactly the opposite. It says:
The damage done by high doses of radiation normally becomes evident within hours or days. Cancers, however, take many years—usually decades—to emerge. And, by definition, the hereditary malformations and diseases caused by generic damage take generations to show; it is the children, grandchildren, or remoter descendants of the people originally irradiated who will be affected.
Although there is currently a national standard for limiting occupational exposure to ionising radiation, this bill will allow the Commonwealth to impose licence conditions on Commonwealth employees and contractors dealing with controlled material or operating controlled apparatus.
This is the first time that a body—the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency—will be established in Australia. It will have a function, amongst others, to oversee and regulate activities that involve radiation and nuclear safety and to provide a mechanism where people's complaints can be heard. It is expected that ARPANSA, as I will refer to it from now on, will be set up from 1 July 1998.
This bill is needed to provide a proper legislative basis for the regulation of the nuclear installations and radiation activities of the Commonwealth, none of which are presently regulated. Indeed, it would not be incorrect to say that whilst radiation exposure was covered by state laws, there persisted a regulatory gap because the laws often did not apply to the Commonwealth or its employees, and this was stated in the 1996 report, No time to waste. Thus, the bill will provide the basis for a uniform national approach to regulation of radiation activity and it will be reflected in due course in the legislation of state and territory jurisdictions for the first time.
A major function of the bill will be to allow for the establishment of a statutory officer, a chief executive officer, who will be empowered to make regulations and set licence conditions for the health and safety of persons and for the protection of the environment. It will also be the CEO's function to ensure that all practical steps are taken to avoid conflicts between regulatory, research and service functions.
In establishing certain safety standards, ARPANSA will ensure that Commonwealth users adhere to them by requiring all the radiation sources and nuclear facilities owned by the Commonwealth to be licensed. The organisation will also be empowered to audit performance of Commonwealth operators and users so as to enforce compliance with standards and codes of practice and to impose penalties for significant deficiencies. The ability to impose charges on licences will be introduced at the same time, as will the annual charges for facility licences and for source licences.
ARPANSA will be formed by drawing together the resources and expertise of the Australian Radiation Laboratory and the Nuclear Safety Bureau, both of which are within the Department of Health and Family Services. Currently, ARL provides advice, research and services on the health and medical aspects of radiation, whilst the NSB reviews and monitors the nuclear safety of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation's nuclear operations.
Because of the specialist expertise of ARL and NSB, the amalgamation of these two bodies will provide a strong and uniform regulatory environment in line with international best practice.	At the same time, ARPANSA will fill the regulatory gap currently left by dealings involving radioactive material that are not already done by government.
It is also important to note that new functions—such as regulation of a new research reactor, X-ray apparatus used by Customs, and medical and industrial radiography by Defence and other departments—will be fully cost recovered by licence fees. Large organisations will be issued with licences that cover multiple radiation sources and will be required to pay annual licence fees based on the numbers and types of sources. However, the government will continue to provide funding at the present level for the existing functions of both ARL and NSB. Any moneys raised by ARPANSA from charges for the provision of services will be retained by the agency, as currently happens with ARL and NSB, to cover the cost of existing functions.
As I have said already, all Commonwealth bodies that use radiation which may affect the health and wellbeing of the public, employees and the environment will be regulated by ARPANSA. These include research agencies such as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, the CSIRO, and a variety of radiation users that I have already mentioned. Consultations with these bodies have taken place, and they will continue.
The Commonwealth's radiation protection and nuclear safety activities which need regulatory controls at Commonwealth level include: the operation and decommissioning of ANSTO's nuclear research reactors and the disposal of spent nuclear fuel: the siting, design, commissioning, operation and eventual decommissioning of the proposed replacement research reactor; the Maralinga rehabilitation project; the establishment of a near-surface radioactive waste repository; and the current and future radiation activities of Commonwealth entities, including the use of X-ray equipment and radioactive sources, and the use of non-ionising radiation sources such as lasers, radar and general microwave sources.
This legislation will ensure arms-length decision making responsibilities for the CEO of ARPANSA. Such decisions can therefore be made free from government and other stakeholders and ensure appropriate separation as recommended in the Senate select committee report No time to waste.
The CEO will prepare and give to the minister quarterly and annual reports on his or her functions which will be tabled in each house of parliament within 15 days of receipt. Additionally the CEO may arrange reports in the parliament at any time provided the minister has been given a copy of that report.
In keeping with this government's philosophy, public scrutiny, input and comments will be sought in the preparation of standards and codes of practice on radiation, health and nuclear safety. There will be community representation on appropriate committees and working parties responsible for advising ARPANSA and the minister through the CEO.
This bill has been prepared following extensive consultations with the states and territories whereby a template was developed which defines a common general shape, an approach to radiation protection legislation. Indeed this bill follows very closely that template and is consistent with both state and territory laws.
Let me just briefly now turn to the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998. This bill will deal with matters arising from the enactment of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and for related 
 purposes. Schedule 1 repeals those parts of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987 that created the Nuclear Safety Bureau and ANSTO safety review committee. These changes are very necessary because once the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 is passed the NSB will be incorporated into the new ARPANSA and the safety review committee will become redundant.
Schedule 2 provides for the transfer of assets and liabilities of the NSB to the Commonwealth. It also provides for the CEO of ARPANSA to have all the powers and functions conferred on the director of NSB in relation to ANSTO during the transition period, the period of six months beginning on the day on which the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 commences.
It is pleasing to know that not only has the third Howard budget delivered a surplus but it has increased nuclear research funding by more than $60 million over the next three years.
—How much?
—ANSTO has been allocated $80 million. The first sum was $60 million. ANSTO has been allocated $80 million this year towards the new research reactor at Lucas Heights in Sydney and the overseas shipment of spent nuclear fuel rods. By making these allocations the government demonstrates its commitment to the high standards within the industry.
Before I conclude I just want to point out that ANSTO only recently, as late as this weekend, announced that it was able to win a substantial contract to help build new nuclear facilities in Thailand. It is also pleasing to know that in doing that, they will be using mainly Australian content, which is very good for our economy and of course also for our employment situation.
I want to conclude as I started. Regulating activities that involve radiation and nuclear safety is extremely important. The setting up of ARPANSA is therefore welcomed and I am sure everybody in this parliament would agree with that, as the measures that are contained in this bill will ensure that regulation does take place. It is important that the health and safety, not only of the people who work within that industry, but indeed of the whole of our country, are protected at all levels so that we can continue to work within this industry, with certainty and safety.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Lee, Michael, MP
text:
—I apologise for not being able to speak earlier in this debate but there was another matter in the House of Representatives chamber at that time.
The  Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 , the  Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998  and the  Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill 1998  establish the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, ARPANSA, covering all Commonwealth agencies where they involve radiation and nuclear safety. As several previous speakers have mentioned, the legislation flows from the Senate select inquiry report entitled No time to waste.
ARPANSA will be a user-pays entity. The legislation seeks to address conflicts of interest between regulatory, research and service functions. The chief executive officer of ARPANSA will regulate Commonwealth activities which involve radiation and nuclear safety. It will also work with the states and territories to develop uniform regulatory controls, will advise the government and the public about radiation protection and safety and will undertake related research. The legislation also establishes the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council to give advice to the chief executive officer.
The government claims the bill will result in a centre of excellence for regulation, advice, research and services supporting nuclear safety and radiation protection for employees, the public and the environment. This bill comes from, as I mentioned, the No time to waste report of the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste. That committee was established in March 1995 and the opposition is very pleased to see the legislation now before the parliament. We note, however, that the explanatory memorandum states that the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council will include, amongst others, consumer groups. While it says that in the explanatory memorandum, it is not required under the legislation and it is, I understand, not mentioned in the second reading speech. Therefore, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for the appointment by the Minister to the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council of a representative of local government and a representative of affected community groups.'
For the information of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Ms Worth), I understand we cannot have votes in this chamber, so that ends up being determined in the House of Representatives.
—Debate may continue in this chamber, but you cannot take a vote. If you wish to have an amendment voted on, it will have to go to the parliament.
—The reason we are moving this amendment is that we believe it is very important that the community at large is represented on that advisory council. Of course, local government has been playing a very important role in the debate about what should be the future of nuclear research in Australia. I note the presence of the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) in the chamber. I am sure she is aware of the controversy about the Lucas Heights reactor in her own electorate. I will say a bit more about that later.
For her information, one of the reasons I am moving this amendment is that David Hill, the Labor candidate who will be elected the member for Hughes at the next election, has spoken to me about the community concern about the government's changes in this area. As a result of my discussions with David, we will be making sure that this amendment seeks to provide a guarantee that local government and local residents are represented on the advisory council. We think this is something that is worthy of support. We will be watching very carefully how the member for Hughes decides to cast her vote on this proposal. For the information of the member for Hughes, the proposal will come to a vote not here but in the other chamber at some time in the future.
—She hasn't seen the amendment yet.
—It has just been circulated in the Main Committee. The amendment asks the government to withdraw this bill and to redraft it so the advisory council does include a representative from local government and a representative from community groups.
I will go through some of the background as to why we think this is an issue which will be of vital importance to local residents in the Sutherland Shire area in southern Sydney and also to the local councils in that area. If anyone was listening to the AM program this morning, they would have heard that the nuclear reprocessing plant in the United Kingdom that is reprocessing some of the Lucas Heights waste has had some difficulties. There is now apparently some doubt about the manner in which the Australian nuclear waste will be reprocessed and the form in which that material might be returned to Australia. That in itself 
 means that this is a very topical issue. We do not quite know what is going to happen to waste that we thought was going to be reprocessed in the United Kingdom.
I draw the attention of the Main Committee to an article by Murray Hogarth in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 September, headed `Revealed: reactor rods corroded by water'. The article begins:
Water has breached the supposedly airtight `dry storage' tubes for the highly radioactive spent fuel rods at Lucas Heights nuclear reactor, a document obtained by the Herald  reveals.
The water became contaminated by `fission products'—produced when nuclear fuel is used—says a briefing note for Sutherland Shire Council by a member of the reactor's confidential Safety Review Committee. The only community representative on the committee, Dr Garry Smith, reported in the note this week that in the most extreme case 90 litres of water had half-flooded a 15-metre-deep sealed storage tube.
`These tubes were designed to be dry and filled with an inert gas to prevent corrosion of the highly radioactive fuel, he reported. ` A number of rods have corroded and released radioactive fission products into the water.'
Dr Smith advised that an urgent investigation was required because he feared that ground-water off the site might become contaminated, despite reactor officials having said that the leaks were caused by rainwater.
The revelation highlights fears surrounding the safety of storing old fuel rods at the 39-year-old reactor, and coincides with this week's Federal Government decision to build a new $300 million reactor at the site.
To be fair to ANSTO, the article goes on later to state:
But the executive director of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), Professor Helen Garnett, confirmed yesterday that water had infiltrated parts of the main storage system.
`It could well be that water has been there for several years.' Tests had shown that the source of the water was rain, discounting Dr Smith's ground-water concern. `I would prefer it did not happen,' Professor Garnett said. `But it is not a safety or environmental hazard to anybody.'
ANSTO and the Federal Government have said repeatedly that the crowded and aging stockpile of about 1,600 spent fuel rods is safe.
But the Mayor of Sutherland, Councillor Kevin Schreiber, said a `serious breach of safety standards' had been revealed. Dr Smith is Sutherland Council's principal environmental scientist.
`I don't see how the minister can continue to refuse a full and independent inquiry into ANSTO's nuclear fuel storage when serious breaches such as these have occurred and are still to be publicly reported by ANSTO,' Cr Schreiber said.
An article by Simon Grose in the Canberra Times on 26 September 1997 is headed `Lucas Heights exceeds own emission levels, criticised over audit methods' and it begins:
The Nuclear Safety Bureau has found that the Australia Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation's HIFAR nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights has not complied with audit criteria for the documentation of procedures and validation of monitoring methods.
In its 39th quarterly report for the three months to June 30, the bureau also reported that:
. Discharges from HIFAR of argon-41, a short-lived radioactive gas produced during the preparation of radio isotopes, exceeded levels set by ANSTO but were low compared with levels recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council.
. ANSTO had agreed to radiographically examine above-ground welds in the reactor's secondary cooling system but examination of underground welds may not be undertaken.
Despite these findings, the report concluded that the operational safety of the reactor was satisfactory during the period. 

The director of the bureau, Donald Macnab, told The Canberra Times  yesterday that it looked `at things in a far more conservative fashion than ANSTO does.'
This is very relevant to the need to have local representation on the advisory council. The next paragraph of the article is very relevant to explain the need for local council and community members to be represented on the advisory council. Mr Macnab stated about ANSTO:
Their responsibility is to operate the reactor safely; our responsibility is to look over their shoulders and make sure they do it that way.
If we needed any further evidence that this was an important issue, let me quote from an article in the Sunday Telegraph  of 23 March 1997:
Federal Liberal MP, Mrs Danna Vale, whose seat of Hughes covers the area, has written to Coalition senators urging them to support the inquiry, which will go before the Senate this week.
That is the inquiry that produced the report that has triggered the legislation.
She said that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) had existed at Lucas Heights for 40 years and the community had accepted its existence.
`But this acceptance has only been on the basis that at some stage the facility would close and be relocated to a more appropriate site,' Mrs Vale wrote.
We will be keen to know if that is still the view of the member for Hughes, given the trouble she took to put that in writing to her Senate colleagues.
We in the Labor Party believe that it is very important that the advisory council have, by legislation, local government representation and representatives of local communities. If you were looking at all of the local councils, right across Australia, Sutherland Shire would have the greatest claim to be the representative on that nuclear advisory council, because Sutherland Shire is the only council of Australia that has contained within its area a functioning nuclear reactor. You would have to say that, if Lucas Heights continues to have a nuclear reactor operating, then Sutherland Shire Council should have that right.
Certainly, local government should be represented by law on that advisory council, and I am sure that the National Local Government Association would see the need for Sutherland Shire Council to be local government's representative on that advisory council. The very strong view that I have had from the Labor candidate and the future Labor member for Hughes, David Hill, is that he is going to fight very hard to make sure that the voice of the local residents is heard.
—No-one could fight harder than Danna Vale.
—Order! The honourable member for Dobell has the floor.
—The assistant junior whip, the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) states that no-one will fight harder than Danna Vale. She has not been too successful in having the nuclear reactor shut down and moved to a more appropriate site. That was the view she expressed—
—She is a very successful local member.
—You will make your remarks through the chair. The debate is on the floor.
—She was not too successful on that one.
—Order! I call the member to order through the chair.
—As we know, since that letter was written, the government has announced that it is going to build a new reactor at Lucas Heights. This emphasises the need to make sure 
 that this amendment is carried so that local governments and local residents are represented on the advisory council. There is no point in relying on an explanatory memorandum, or assurances in this chamber, by people such as the parliamentary secretary who, with the best of intentions in the world, might be promoted on a future occasion. If Mr Howard is re-elected, this parliamentary secretary could be the person who is the next minister for health, given the comments on Lateline  last night when the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) said that he wanted another job, basically. Or it might be the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) who becomes the parliamentary secretary looking after nuclear radiation matters. How do we know that any commitments given by the current parliamentary secretary would be bound by—
Government members interjecting—
—In the unlikely event that the Howard government is re-elected—
—Order! I call the member for Dobell and I call—
—In the very unlikely event that this mob gets back, what will be even more unlikely is that the member for Fisher ends up a minister in any re-elected government of the coalition. But even if the current parliamentary secretary gives us an assurance that local government and local communities will be represented on the advisory council, we have got no guarantee that that will be followed by a future minister for health, or a future parliamentary secretary, and that is why we need to make sure. There is even a possibility that this minister might give an assurance and then not keep it. But we know that would be unlikely.
The only way we can guarantee that the residents of the Sutherland Shire and local government are represented on this advisory committee is to have this amendment carried, to require the legislation to be withdrawn, and for the legislation to be amended to guarantee that these two groups are represented on the advisory council. I would be very interested to know the views of the honourable member for Hughes on the amendment.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Vale, Danna, MP
text:
—It just absolutely amazes me to hear the comments from the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) on this particular legislation. Would that his party had acted on it in the 13 years that they were in government, and would that they had acted on it even after their own report from the reactor research review was handed down in 1993 when they had three years to act on the recommendations in that report. Would that that had happened. There would have been a lot greater protection for me, my family and my constituents in this particular area.
This can be absolutely nothing but a political stunt. He talks about having representation from the local council and their representatives. Of course they are going to be on this committee. The regulations will cover that. As a matter of fact, the member for Dobell and his friends on the other side of the House might be interested to know that it has been the subject of some lobbying on my part since August last year, before this was before the cabinet.
I extend my gratitude to my government, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and cabinet, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Ms Worth), for actually having this legislation today before the House for debate. And isn't it just typical of the member for Dobell to say that he wants this amendment put in when it is going to delay the progress of this important legislation through the House? It is important for my constituents because for the first time in 40 years, since the establishment of that facility, they are going to have an agency that will protect the people and the environment.
It will be responsible to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), not the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore). It will actually operate at arms-length from the activities of ANSTO—and that is not to take anything away from the activities of ANSTO at all, not in any way whatsoever. This is in keeping with what is understood now in practice worldwide: to have an independent regulatory agency that will act for the people and for the protection of the people and the environment.
The government is to be commended because it is acting in that regard, and this is the recommendation from the review committee. It absolutely appals me that this facility has existed for 40 years without this kind of regulatory authority. It has taken this government and this member to get up there and force this through. I am grateful that they have listened. They have listened because it is important to my government, it is important to the Prime Minister and it is important to every member of cabinet that my constituents can be assured that they have the protection of this agency, and that is exactly what they are going to get.
I will now continue with my formal speech. It gives me great pleasure to rise today to welcome the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 , together with enabling bills to cover licensing charges and consequential amendments. I have a particular and special interest in seeing this legislation come into force because Australia's only nuclear reactor is in my electorate of Hughes.
It is located in the bushland suburb of Lucas Heights and it is operated by the Australian Nuclear Scientific and Technology Organisation. I will correct something here so that the parliament understands where it is situated. While it may be in a bushland suburb, there is still a buffer zone of almost two kilometres around the facility. The house that was the closest to ANSTO, when it was first established back in 1958, is still the closest residence to the establishment. But it is located in bushland and I think that should be noted for the record.
It should also be noted that the bushland—I think the buffer zone is 1.6 to nearly two kilometres around—is a feral proofed area. Within that area, there is a population of wallabies and kangaroos which apparently grow so very well there that they are culled and used to stock national parks throughout New South Wales. That is just a bit of additional information about how well the establishment is operated.
The reactor is a research reactor, and let me explain to members here how that differs from a power reactor: this reactor operates at 10 megawatts, whereas a power reactor operates at 3,000 megawatts. By way of history, the reactor was built at Lucas Heights in the Sutherland Shire in the mid-1950s. It was completed in 1958. I was a child living in the shire at Sylvania at the time, and I can recall the excitement in the local community about the reactor being built. It was considered to be a significant scientific milestone for Australia to have such a facility, and children in schools across Sydney were encouraged and inspired to study science and to look towards science in their future careers.
The research reactor has now been operating in my neighbourhood for almost 40 years. At that time, and, most importantly, in recent years, with the significant growth in world consciousness about scientific safety and environmental protection, the facility established a sound safety record, which it scrupulously maintains in accord with community expectations. The facility employs between 800 and 900 local people, many of whom are my constituents and, with its policy of positive support for local businesses and tradespeople, it contributes over $50 million to the economy of my electorate.
In the wider Australian context, it produces nuclear isotopes which are used in the delivery of diagnostic and therapeutic services to thousands of Australians. As a matter of fact, the isotopes produced at Lucas Heights save many Australian lives and are depended upon by an increasing number of Australians as medical science expands and adapts its application of nuclear medicine.
I did hear what the member for Dobell said about the use of cyclotrons. But cyclotrons, I am informed, do not, and cannot, produce the full extent and the high sophistication isotopes that are produced from a nuclear facility. That is something that I am sure the member for Dobell will learn about as he proceeds with this debate.
However, it has long been a concern of mine that, although the facility has been operating safely now for 40 years, its regulatory regime has been significantly inadequate for the operation of this kind of facility. Given the growing world consciousness regarding health and safety issues, and the heightened awareness of our responsibility to our environment over the last decade and a half, it is amazing that the previous government never had the political will to provide a proper legislative basis for the appropriate regulation of nuclear installations and radiation activities in Australia.
The facility was thought to operate under conditions laid down by the International Atomic Energy Agency, but this was dismissed by the research reactor review in 1993. So the other side has well had notice of this situation. Up to now, ANSTO has operated under authorisation issued by its board to its executive director. The Nuclear Safety Bureau had referred to this as, amongst other things, a de facto licence. Minutes from meetings of the safety review committee show that in certain areas of operation there has been regular confusion between the Nuclear Safety Bureau and ANSTO as to who has jurisdiction in certain areas of operation.
Although the International Atomic Energy Agency has set the ground rules for independent regulation of the nuclear industry by which most countries abide, the previous Labor government had allowed the situation to drift along. The research reactor review, in 1993, concluded that this state of affairs could no longer be allowed to continue, but the previous government did absolutely nothing in the next three years of its office to change this situation. Its negligence and inactivity in this regard was nothing short of a national disgrace.
As a long-time resident in the shire and neighbourhood of Australia's only nuclear research reactor, I have long been very concerned about this situation and very much aware that my family—and, since 1996, my constituents—did not have the protection of legislation to regulate such activities in the interests of health, safety and the environment. It has been of immense personal concern to me since my election as the member for Hughes to ensure that proper regulation comes to fruition. It is with immense personal satisfaction that I have been able to successfully lobby the government and the cabinet to take the actions necessary to put into legislation the recommendations of the research reactor review in this regard.
The prime object of these bills is to protect the health and safety of the people of Australia, and to protect the unique Australian environment. These bills give effect to the cabinet decision to enact legislation to provide this protection by the regulation of all the Commonwealth's radiation and nuclear activities, and to provide the statutory base for the regulatory safety agency, to be called the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, ARPANSA.
As directed by cabinet, the resources and expertise of the Australian Radiation Laboratory, ARL and the Nuclear Safety Bureau, NSB, to form the Australian Radiation Protection and 
 Nuclear Safety Agency comes within the health and family services portfolio. Both the ARL and the NSB are health and family services portfolio agencies. The Australian Radiation Laboratory currently provides advice, research and services on the health and medical aspects of radiation. The Nuclear Safety Bureau reviews and monitors the nuclear safety of ANSTO's nuclear operations. Because of the high specialist expertise of both these bodies, their amalgamation as ARPANSA will provide a strong and informed regulatory environment in line with international best practice.
ARPANSA will establish a regulatory scheme to oversee the operation of the Lucas Heights facility and the management of radiation sources, including ionising material and apparatus and non-ionising apparatus, where such activities are undertaken by the Commonwealth, Commonwealth entities and all those who do business with such entities. This legislation will provide a complete independent oversight body for the better protection and assurance of all my constituents. Most importantly for my constituents, a Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council will be established under the legislation and there will be capacity within the working groups for local representation.
It will apply to all Commonwealth departments, including the Department of Defence. It will apply to corporate bodies of the Commonwealth, like ANSTO and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and Commonwealth business enterprises, like Australian Isotopes. It will apply also to non-Commonwealth contractors working under contract to one of the aforementioned entities—for example, the public company Thiess, which is already contracted to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for the Maralinga clean-up operation.
All Commonwealth bodies that use radiation which may affect the health or wellbeing of members of the Australian public, employees or the environment will be regulated by ARPANSA. These include a variety of radiation users such as the Department of Customs, Australia Post and airport surveillance operators.
ARPANSA will also impose regulatory controls on the operation and decommissioning of ANSTO's research reactor and the disposition of spent fuel. It will regulate and license each stage of the life of the replacement research reactor. This will include the siting, design, construction, operation and eventual decommissioning of the proposed replacement research reactor, which will only be authorised to proceed by ARPANSA when the agency is totally satisfied that there will be no undue risk to the health and safety of persons or the local environment.
Many of my constituents have expressed real and justifiable concern about the storage of radioactive wastes on the site at ANSTO. This is also a matter which I have brought to the attention of this government. That we have not had a proper place to store Australia's radioactive waste is because of a lack of interest by successive federal governments, most especially the previous Labor government, whose member for the seat of Hughes then was also a minister of that government for eight years. What possible defence can be offered to the constituents of Hughes for such disinterest and neglect over 13 years in office?
Now we have the member for Dobell standing up and acting as if all of a sudden it is the most important concern in the hearts of those opposite, when they had 13 years to do something about it for my constituents. Constipated by their own inactivity and ineptitude in the face of such a challenge, and in careless disregard for the people of my electorate, the 
 previous Labor government allowed a de facto nuclear waste dump to be created in my electorate of Hughes at Lucas Heights.
In the conclusion to section 17 of the research reactor review of 1993, which was Labor's research review, one of the review's onerous conditions was the crucial issue of the `final disposal of high level wastes, which depends on identification of a site and investigation of its characteristics'. It went on to say:
A solution to this problem is essential to any future decision about a new reactor.
Since that review, the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste was convened. Part of its report was a recommendation that an above-ground dry storage repository be built on an appropriate site suitable to store all levels of radioactive waste. Such a repository would ensure that the waste was safe, secure and retrievable so that if and when permanent disposal methods are developed they can be put into action.
ARPANSA will also regulate the establishment of a national nuclear surface radioactive waste repository. This national repository will provide for low- and intermediate-level waste suitable for shallow ground burial and arrangements for the safe storage of material not suitable for disposal in this way.
Waste generated from nuclear reactor operation is a real problem and is of great concern to me and my constituents. It is with significant interest and appreciation that we welcome this government's announcement of its selection of a designated site in South Australia, near Maralinga, and its decision to set up an environmental impact statement to investigate this site's suitability as a national repository for radioactive waste, as recommended by the Senate select committee. It is this government that is doing that. This government is committed to the health and wellbeing of the Australian people and the Australian environment. Its actions in implementing the recommendations of the Senate select committee show that commitment.
ARPANSA will work to develop jointly with the states and territories guidelines for the safe management of all radioactive wastes produced in Australia. In line with this government's determination to regulate Commonwealth entities, it will prohibit those entities from dealing with radioactive materials, radiation apparatus like X-ray machines, lasers, microwave transmitters and nuclear facilities, including the nuclear research reactors and the radioactive waste repositories, unless licensed to do so.
It is important for my constituents to note that these bills will provide that compliance with licences, that conditions will be monitored, and that penalties will be imposed for breaches. It will also empower the gathering of evidence to support any prosecutions. Generally speaking, Commonwealth agencies and ANSTO have been responsible in protecting the health and safety of their employees and the public. I make the point that, rather than there being any evident need of regulation of ANSTO by the safety agency, it is not only appropriate but long overdue, in view of the contemporary world standards and public expectations, that such a body be subject to independent scrutiny by an agency with the necessary regulatory powers.
This legislation will assure my constituents and all Australians that ANSTO continues to operate at, and meets the criteria of, international best practice. ARPANSA will maintain involvement with international organisations, such as the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation, the International Commission on Radiological Protection, the International Commission on Non-Ionising Radiation Protection, the International Atomic Energy Agency and the World Health Organisation. Best practice will be ensured by incorporating their guidance into regulations and codes of practice. My constituents can be 
 assured by this government that Australia is a party to international conventions on nuclear safety and radioactive waste management.
It is important to note that the bill will provide ARPANSA with a statutory chief executive officer who will: establish the protocol for the regulation of activities of radiation and nuclear safety; jointly with the states and territories develop uniform protection and safety controls throughout Australia to protect workers, the public and the environment; provide advice on radiation protection and nuclear safety to the government and the public; and undertake research and provide services of a high standard to ensure radiation protection and nuclear safety.
The council's functions will include advising the chief executive officer on matters of nuclear safety and radiation protection. There will also be capacity in the council's working groups to have local representation from members of the public. Furthermore, any concerns from the general public will also be able to be investigated by this agency at arm's length from the operations of ANSTO itself.
It is to be noted again that this legislation is under the portfolio of the minister for health and not the minister for science, again signalling to the constituents of Hughes that it will operate at the strictest possible level of independence from ANSTO.
I congratulate cabinet on its direction on this legislation, and I congratulate the government and the minister for health. I congratulate also the parliamentary secretary for the work she has done in bringing this important legislation to fruition. It demonstrates to my constituents and to the world not only that this government is proud of the achievements at ANSTO but that it will move also to assure the constituents of Hughes they will have the greatest possible protection. It is with pleasure I commend this legislation to the House.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Cobb, Michael, MP
text:
—I wish to contribute to this cognate debate on the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 , the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill 1998 , and the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998 . I particularly want to congratulate the previous speaker, the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale), for her excellent and well prepared speech. Her local constituents must be very proud to have such a diligent and energetic member. I am sure she will continue to represent them into the future.
The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 is about establishing a scheme for the Commonwealth to oversee the operation of radiation sources in Australia that are produced by the Commonwealth or by Commonwealth entities. That can include such mundane things as Customs running X-ray machines right through to the grander nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights that the previous member spoke about.
The government has set up a regulatory framework to do this because it did not exist before—quite surprisingly, I have to say. The states and territories look after things that are produced by states and territories and private undertakings but there has been no fully comparable regulatory and oversighting body to look after Commonwealth agencies until this time. There are many departments and entities that are involved here, including the Department of Defence, CSIRO and ANSTO.
I want to join with the previous speaker in congratulating the staff of ANSTO for the tremendous work they have done for Australia in recent decades in saving lives through the medical aspects of radioisotopes, and also for the work they have done, which is not as well 
 recognised, in assisting the environment and assisting industrial safety through their necessary and very valuable work at Lucas Heights.
From 1 July this year the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Australian Radiation Laboratory will be combined, in a sense, into this new body called ARPANSA, and it will be managed by a CEO. It will be an independent statutory office that will provide independent scrutiny of such bodies. It will apply world's best practice to these activities and it will endeavour to get uniform regulatory controls throughout Australia.
It will advise the government where appropriate about safety and protection. It will issue Commonwealth entities with licences so that you will need a licence to operate. It will monitor and enforce compliance and it will have the power where necessary to gather evidence for prosecutions if there are any transgressions.
In short, this is all being set up for the safety of the public and for the safety of the environment. I am particularly interested to see that it is being done in such a way that it is not being too prescriptive. It will be quite flexible because this is an area which is evolving and changing all the time.
For the rest of my comments I particularly want to speak about what may happen in Australia in the future and how this body will be beneficial in advising the government and ensuring the safety of the public and the environment. Thoughts that I have had in this area as to what might happen with nuclear radiation and power in this country were crystallised recently with an article I read by that eminent scientist Leslie Kemeny. He nowadays is the scientific and technical editor of the International Nuclear Energy Academy. He is a director of his own company as a consulting engineer and physician. He puts some interesting thoughts down on paper. It is relevant because we have finished within the last few weeks the Kyoto climate summit in which they talked about lowering greenhouse gas emissions around the world.
I was disturbed with the great push of the Greens and the left wing in this country in wanting, without great thought, to shut down to a large degree the coal industry in Australia which does earn $7 billion to $8 billion of export income. I am the first to admit there is going to be increasing pressure on the coal industry in the future. What those critics did not talk about is what happens if this is wound down and what alternative energy sources we will have in this country. In particular let us have a decent debate about nuclear energy.
It is interesting to look at the types of energy production sources around the world such as they exist. Hydro energy of course has been traditionally quite important. In Australia it generates about 10 per cent of our electricity. Canada is the highest. It generates about 60 per cent of its electricity there. But, generally speaking, the opportunities for expansion of this are quite limited and, even if there are good sites to build dams in the future, they are going to be increasingly difficult to do because of the environmental push.
Oil I do not think is an alternative for electricity production. It is far too expensive and far too valuable a resource. Gas does have considerable possibilities particularly in Australia that is gas rich and we should look at this more and more.
Coal has traditionally been burnt for electricity around the world particularly in Australia. The United States produces about 60 per cent of electricity from coal, Australia about 80 per cent and the rest of the world, including Europe, something of the order of 15 to 30 per cent. Coal is quite polluting. It churns out tremendous amounts of carbon dioxide as well as acid rain products like sulfur dioxide and has been known to poison literally thousands of lakes 
 across Europe including in what we think are environmentally clean countries like Sweden. We are going to have to look more and more at the damage that coal does in the future.
Solar power, while having a definite role, nevertheless is very limited in its use. It is very expensive. It is quite polluting in the sense that you have got to go out there and mine all these metals and minerals to make solar panels. If you were going to supply for example the city of Sydney with solar power, and that was to be the only source of power, you would probably want at least several hundred square kilometres of panels occupying the environment somewhere in this country. It does have its limitations, as desirable as it is. It is unreliable. I have White Cliffs in my electorate, for example. If there is a town in Australia on which the sun beats down on a regular basis, it is White Cliffs, but even there it was not successful in providing an electricity source.
The other source of energy is nuclear power. France already produces more than 70 per cent of its electricity via this source and Sweden produces a little less. What does Australia produce from this source? Absolutely zero. It is one of the very few countries in the world, particularly developed countries, that does not produce any of its electricity from nuclear power. As we move into the 21st century that is perhaps an irresponsible position to be in. I think Australia has to look more to that.
We produce about 175 terawatt hours of electricity in this country, which is a very small amount compared with the United States, which produces 3,500 terawatt hours. Nevertheless, we have to make our contribution. As more and more pressure is put on us to get down our carbon dioxide greenhouse gas emissions, this is something that we cannot ignore. Electricity generation is a very high energy growth area around the world, not only in the established economies of the world but also in the developing countries. Nuclear power is overall providing 17 per cent of that but that is growing rapidly indeed.
Nuclear power, despite the tragedy and the horror of Chernobyl, still has the best track record of all the energy sources. It provides extremely clean power. The emissions are almost zero. It is becoming more and more cost-competitive, and the supply of it is unlimited. Until we move to fusion power, this is something we are going to have to look more at in this country.
Australia, it can be said, has very high and cheap coal supplies close to the markets. If we switch to nuclear power, particularly in the eastern part of the country, it would be more expensive to provide electricity at this stage. However, we have just seen the Loy Yang A 2,000-megawatt plant in Victoria, which runs on brown coal, sold to Horizon Energies for $4,855 million—a considerable sum of money. That happened last year. It makes you wonder just how much longer coal is going to beat uranium as a competitive energy source in this country.
It was interesting at the Kyoto climate conference that those who were criticising Australia's contribution were sitting there in the international convention centre in that magnificent city, reading their documents from the light that was provided and enjoying the airconditioning from power at least partly supplied by 54 nuclear power stations throughout Japan.
If some of the more extreme elements of that conference had had their way and had been able to shut down nuclear power in Japan, then those 54 nuclear power stations would have had to switch to, say, coal and that would have pumped out another 287 million tonnes of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Think about that. Because those 54 nuclear power stations are allowed to operate, and operate as cleanly as they do, they are saving the polluting of the 
 world's atmosphere to the tune of 287 million tonnes equivalent of carbon dioxide every year. That is equivalent, in round figures, to about three-quarters of Australia's total emissions alone. So it is food for thought, indeed.
Australia mines a lot of uranium. We are very rich in uranium: we have about 30 per cent of the world's reserves, even though we only sell about 10 per cent of the world's supply, because of restrictions that we have had in this country with the two-mine and three-mine policies. Our uranium is sold to approximately 11 countries, including Japan, so that the light and the airconditioning that the delegates who were critical of our policy at Kyoto were enjoying was actually supplied by Australia's uranium. I do not know whether they ever stopped to think of that.
We mine uranium in this country in the Northern Territory and in South Australia. It is interesting to contemplate that to dig 25 tonnes of uranium out of the ground and send it to an overseas country—and we sell several thousand tonnes of it per year—saves one million tonnes of carbon dioxide belching into the atmosphere every year, when that uranium is used for electricity generation—which all of it is used for: none of it goes into nuclear weapons, of course.
During the Kyoto conference, the ABC was running opinions from every nut case and fruit loop that Australia was able to put up—some of them coming from the Senate. All I thought they were demonstrating was a lack of intellectual honesty and a pious and arrogant disloyalty to Australian workers and Australian taxpayers, let alone to the environment overall. It seemed to me that no credible alterative was ever put at any stage in terms of what was supposed to be replacing coal in the short term. No doubt, if you had mentioned nuclear energy, they would have gone into some sort of tailspin themselves.
The fact of the matter is that the world has 445 nuclear power plants operating now, and another 35 are being built. If we closed those down and switched to coal, we would be belching out another 2,300 million tonnes of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere every year. On balance, they are doing the environment a service, and this should be applauded. By all means we should continue to strive for safer nuclear power plants. In former Communist countries where they have run shoddy plants—
—Chernobyl.
—Such as Chernobyl.
—You have been there, or close to it.
—I have been close to Chernobyl: Bulgaria was the closest I got to it. We have to put pressure on those countries to pull those plants into line. But, where they are run properly, we have no particular worries.
—India is a worry.
—The member for Bradfield remarks that India is a worry. India, in its recent actions, has been incredibly irresponsible. But what we are debating today is about the clean and safe production of nuclear energy to generate electricity, and not about the detonating of bombs.
The Australian Conservation Foundation in October last year proposed an $8 per tonne carbon tax in this country, which would have added about 0.22c per kilowatt hour to the cost of electricity in this country. The more pressure they put on the coal industry in this country, the more pressure there is going to be for a nuclear power plant to be established.
Until now, hydrocarbon energy production in the world has been in many ways quite wasteful, often quite expensive and, as I have said, very polluting. The only reason they are getting away with it is that often you cannot see what is being belched out. You can see a bit of smoke coming out a smokestack, but each of these smokestacks is dropping into the atmosphere what are often thousands of tonnes of pollutants, some of which are actually radioactive. Many people do not realise it, but there are radioactive elements in coal and, when it is burnt, if the filters particularly are not working well on the stacks of these plants, these radioactive elements are poured out into the atmosphere to a disturbing degree. That fact has to be considered, as well.
I believe that the hydrocarbons in this world are becoming more limited and a lot of thought has to be given to rationing them to supply the feedstock requirements of the industrial, agricultural, pharmaceutical and chemical industries of this country. These are some thoughts that I have laid out for consideration. I believe that this bill today, which sets up a regulatory mechanism, will be well placed and will have the framework to be able to regulate such industries if we get to that stage in this country. I say `if we get to that stage', though it is, of course, inevitable. Some people might deny it but, even if nuclear power generation in this country is some time off, it will come some time next century, and probably sooner than people realise.
With those closing comments I congratulate the government for setting up these regulatory mechanisms in the way that they have. It has been long overdue in this country; it is quite remarkable that it has not happened before. I congratulate the government and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) for their foresight and diligence in this area.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Wakelin, Barry, MP
text:
—The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998, as we know, introduces a regulatory control for all Commonwealth radiation and nuclear safety activities in Australia. The bill will protect the health and safety of the people and environments that are subject to radioactive practices undertaken by the Commonwealth. It will apply to Commonwealth entities, employees and those non-government entities contracted by the Commonwealth, for example, Defence, CSIRO and ANSTO. In fact, a Commonwealth entity must be licensed by this legislation in order to deal with radioactive materials, equipment and nuclear facilities. There are certain exemptions, notably for defence and national security purposes.
The origin of the bill was a recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on the Danger of Radioactive Waste which identified a regulatory deficiency in this field. State and territory governments have been particularly supportive of this reining in of unchecked Commonwealth powers. From 1 July, the functions and resources of the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Australian Radiation Laboratory will combine to form the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency which will be part of the Department of Health and Family Services. The role of the agency will be to regulate Commonwealth activities involving radiation and nuclear safety; to work with states and territories to develop uniform regulations; to inform and advise the government and the public on radiation protection and nuclear safety, and undertake related research. This organisation will be responsible for the regulation of the proposed national radioactive waste repository and will be responsible for ensuring the safety of that facility. I will now just talk to that repository for a minute or two.
The history of the low level radioactive waste, particularly that which has been stored in the Sutherland Shire in Sydney and in other areas, has been well documented. In 1994 the 
 waste was transferred to Commonwealth land in Woomera and the government has proceeded with the repository proposal to stage 3, with stages 1 and 2 going back something like 10 or 15 years.
It is pleasing that the government has introduced this legislation to cover, as I have already said, flaws and gaps in the legislation to make sure that this important community issue is dealt with in the appropriate way. There is always a concern in the community about these issues. Nevertheless, as a community we have an equal responsibility to manage this material.
There are so many upsides to the usage. In industrial and medical areas there is a whole range of ways this material is used and now we need to have a way whereby we can store it responsibly and in the national interest. I join with the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) in congratulating the government on introducing this bill and I am sure we all wish it well in its future.
debate_title: <title>AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998</title>

name: Worth, Trish, MP
text:
—in reply—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will begin by thanking all members for their contributions in this debate, and especially the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) who, as we have heard today, has put her case for her constituents so well. I can inform other members that she not only puts her case well in debate, as we have heard her so eloquently do today, but also very effectively lobbies everyone from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) down—including on this issue.
I would hate to see any delay of this legislation because of amendments moved by the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). As the member for Hughes has told us, there have been too many delays already. We need to be getting on with this legislation. Labor had 13 years and nothing eventuated. The bill must be seen through to fruition because of not only the constituents of Hughes and the rest of the Australian community but also our international obligations. The grandstanding of the opposition on this when this government is actually doing something positive about it does not stand up to too much scrutiny.
The member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) as well as the member for Dobell raised concerns about the membership of the council. It should be said that the council is to be an expert body. An example that easily comes to mind is the National Health and Medical Research Council. The government considers this proposed council to be important. While the detail is not in this legislation, it will be in the regulations, which are being drafted as we speak.
The regulations will spell out exactly who will be on the council and the types of representation on the council. There will be community representation, state and territory representation and, importantly, expert representation. The member for Dobell was asking questions as to the guarantees I might give that another minister or parliamentary secretary may not live up to. That is not an issue: it will be there in the regulations. The government considers these things to be very important and would not leave it hanging loose like that.
The whole framework for this legislation relies on a lot of detail in regulation and that is entirely appropriate. The member for Bonython also mentioned his concerns about the suitability of Lucas Heights. He should be reminded that a Senate inquiry is under way at the moment on the suitability of Lucas Heights as an appropriate place for the new reactor, and a number of other associated issues as well. I look forward to that report. I understand it will be available at the end of June.
He also expressed concern about the powers granted to inspectors. Most members would want adequate powers available to inspectors, when you consider that community safety and the environment are in question. This is very similar to other Commonwealth enactments where inspectors are required to look at hazardous materials or check for potential hazards. There is one example of this in the Therapeutic Goods Act.
I am sure that any concerns genuinely held by the opposition will be dealt with. I hope it is not just a question of grandstanding. I also hope that we will see this legislation through the House of Representatives and the Senate as quickly as possible, because it is particularly important legislation.
Because it is also reasonably technical I would like to put those technicalities on the record. Today we are debating a series of bills designed to protect the health and safety of persons and the environment from harm arising from radiation practices undertaken by Commonwealth entities. The first bill is the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998, which establishes for the first time a regulatory framework to enable all Commonwealth radiation and nuclear activities to be regulated. The other two bills, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998 and the  Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill 1998 , are adjuncts to the first bill.
The ARPANS bill is a critical piece of legislation which closes a current gap in regulation where the states and territory government activities and private undertakings are regulated by state and territory radiation laws but Commonwealth agencies have operated without corresponding Commonwealth oversight and regulation. The bill applies to all Commonwealth entities and their employees and to non-Commonwealth entities when these are contracted to the Commonwealth. This includes all Commonwealth departments such as Defence, bodies corporate such as CSIRO and ANSTO, and any person who is a party to a contract with a Commonwealth entity.
Under the provisions of the bill, no Commonwealth entity can deal with radioactive materials or radiation apparatus, or any aspects of a nuclear facility, unless licensed to do so in accordance with this legislation. This means that Commonwealth activities ranging from using an X-ray machine to the safe and appropriate decommissioning of the nuclear research reactor at Lucas Heights are prohibited unless a licence has been issued in accordance with this bill. The bill provides for exemptions to the general prohibition, including specific exemptions for certain defence and security activities in the national interest. Criteria for other exemptions on the basis of very low risk will be set out in regulation under this legislation.
There is very broad support for the aims of the bill. The value of legislation such as this has been recognised by all parties in this chamber. In 1996 the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste produced a report, No time to waste, with the close involvement of the Greens, the Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and the current coalition government. In that report the committee made recommendations strongly supporting:
. . . the proposal for an independent regulator of Commonwealth bodies' radiation activities, with functions of regulating, licensing, monitoring and imposing penalties for breaches of licences.
The committee also made recommendations regarding the need to resolve any potential conflict of interest between regulatory and other functions of the new agency and the need for community representation on advisory bodies. I am pleased to report that this bill incorporates 
 all of those recommendations and delivers on the government's commitment to close the regulatory gap identified by the committee.
Regulation of Commonwealth activities is also strongly supported by all state and territory governments. In August last year I presented to all health ministers a strategy for pursuing a national uniform regulatory framework.
