Ministers wholeheartedly supported my proposal and since then the Commonwealth and all states and territories have worked together to produce such a framework. I am pleased to note that this bill has been crafted following close consultation with states and territories and that it complies with the template for nationally uniform radiation protection legislation which was jointly developed by all jurisdictions.
The provisions of this bill have been developed in close consultation with those Commonwealth agencies and departments which will be regulated by this legislation, including ANSTO, Defence, CSIRO, Industry, Science and Tourism, Primary Industries and Energy, Foreign Affairs and Customs. As honourable members would note, the style of this bill is such that it relies heavily on details contained in regulations for its operations. The development of regulations made under this bill will be the subject of the same extensive consultation as has characterised the development of the bill itself. I am sorry that the member for Dobell is not here to hear that detail.
What does this bill do? How will the regulatory framework described in the bill be implemented? The bill provides for the establishment of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency, to be known as ARPANSA, within the Department of Health and Family Services. From 1 July 1998, the functions and resources of the currently existing Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Australian Radiation Laboratory will be combined to form ARPANSA. This agency will also take responsibility for the regulatory matters detailed in the bill.
ARPANSA will be managed by a CEO, an independent statutory office which is created in the bill. The functions of the CEO will include regulating, in accordance with international best practice, activities within the Commonwealth which involve radiation and nuclear safety; working with the states and territories to develop uniform regulatory controls throughout Australia; informing and advising the government and the public on radiation protection and nuclear safety; and undertaking research and providing a service of a high standard to ensure radiation protection and nuclear safety.
It is clearly important that the CEO has access to expert advice and input from a range of sources, including the community. The bill therefore provides for the establishment of the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council. Members of this council will be appointed by the minister for health. The council will include representatives from the community, the states and territories as well as others with appropriate experience. Each member will be appointed on the basis of their standing and their expertise in fields relevant to radiation protection.
The council will oversee the work of a number of standing committees, some of which have already undertaken substantial and important work, including the Radiation Health Committee and the Nuclear Codes Committee. The standing committees will also comprise experts in the field, including community and public interest representatives.
In summary, ARPANSA, under the direction of the CEO, will serve a number of complementary functions. Before I outline those, I say again that I would hope it was not ignorance on the part of the member for Dobell in moving his amendment to this bill, because briefings are available to all shadow ministers when they are required. On something as 
 important as this, and following the Senate committee, I am sure he would have been up to date. From that, I can only conclude that he thought this might be some way to cast a red herring to in some way tarnish the best interests of the government, or perhaps it might have been just playing very local politics in the electorate of Hughes. I say again that no member could have put more effort into this issue than has the member for Hughes, as indeed she does with so many of the other issues that she takes up on behalf of her electorate. I would expect that the people of Hughes would be not pleased with little antics like this and in fact would be pleased to see that legislation is now coming before the parliament following 13 years of neglect in this area from the former government.
To get back to the detail of ARPANSA's functions, it will issue Commonwealth entities with licences in respect of radioactive material, radiation apparatus, and nuclear and other facilities. Attached to each licence will be a series of conditions. It will be an offence under the legislation for a controlled person to deal with controlled materials, apparatus or nuclear and other facilities without a licence or contrary to the licence conditions. Penalties will apply to breaches of the act, regulations and licence conditions.
As ARPANSA will be responsible for monitoring and enforcing compliance with the provisions, it is important that the bill provides for appropriate powers to gather evidence to support prosecutions where necessary. It is the government's view that prosecutions would be an avenue of last resort against its own agencies, but there is no doubt that where a safety breach is significant ARPANSA will have the capacity to respond appropriately.
ARPANSA will continue, and appropriately expand, the excellent research work currently undertaken by the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Australian Radiation Laboratory. It is essential that this regulation is underpinned by an independent research capability. This will include research associated with radiation and nuclear safety, such as public health and environmental issues. ARPANSA will also continue to be involved in international fora. It is also clearly important that Australia's interests in the international arena are well served by an authoritative, independent, expert voice.
The cost of undertaking functions specified in the bill will be recovered, as appropriate, from regulated Commonwealth agencies. In regard to this matter, I draw members' attention to the  Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill 1998  before you. The information on charges is represented in a separate bill because annual charges are treated as taxes and the constitution requires that taxes must be dealt with separately in purpose specific legislation. This bill enables appropriate cost recovery processes by providing for fees and charges to be levied on Commonwealth entities requiring a licence under the legislation. No private individuals or corporations will be required to obtain a licence or to pay any fees.
For the purposes of establishing appropriate annual fees, the Commonwealth will employ an independent consultant to advise on cost recovery. All Commonwealth entities to be levied under this bill will be closely consulted during the project and during the subsequent determination of appropriate charges. It will then be possible to develop regulations under this bill to reflect the fees and charges to be levied.
The third bill which is before us today is the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998. This bill details necessary changes to existing legislation to accommodate the ARPANS bill. The effect of the consequential amendments bill is threefold. Firstly, the bill details changes that are necessary to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987. As a result of the introduction of the 
 ARPANS bill the key change to the ANSTO Act is the repealing of those parts of the act which established the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Safety Review Committee.
As I have previously mentioned, once the ARPANS bill is passed the Nuclear Safety Bureau and the Australian Radiation Laboratory will be combined to form the basis of the new Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency—ARPANSA—within the Department of Health and Family Services. The CEO and staff of the new agency will have responsibility for administering the new legislation and regulating Commonwealth entities involved in radiation and nuclear safety activities. With the establishment of ARPANSA the Safety Review Committee will become redundant.
Secondly, the bill transfers the assets and liabilities of the Nuclear Safety Bureau to the Commonwealth.
Thirdly, the bill ensures that the current powers of the director of the Nuclear Safety Bureau, as set out in the ANSTO Act, are conferred on the CEO of ARPANSA during any transitional period. This will ensure continuity between the present processes and the future regulatory regime. Consequential amendments set out in this bill will ensure the appropriate and seamless operations of the two Commonwealth acts.
In conclusion, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill and associated bills will result in a centre of excellence for regulation, advice, research and services supporting radiation protection and nuclear safety of employees, the public and the environment.
I again thank members for their contribution and commend this bill to the parliament.
—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Dobell has moved an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the ayes have it.
—The noes have it.
—As it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277, the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.

name: Crosio, Janice, MP
text:
—Can I say at the outset that I am actually continuing a debate that was brought on very quickly on 5 March of this year. It is ironic when one thinks that the report that we are talking about, the national report into local government which under the 1995 Commonwealth act requires the minister to table it in the House, should have a little bit more debate than what we seem to be doing. It was brought on very quickly at the end of the session when there were only four or five minutes left to debate the issues and now we seem to be having it again at the end of a Main Committee sitting because we have a few moments left over.
I believe it is doubly ironic that we have got this report now before us just two days after the Commonwealth has brought down its 1998 budget. Prior to that we had the Australian Local Government Association putting pressure on all representatives right across Australia requesting that they get the message over very clearly to the government about the effects of the cuts that had occurred in the 1997 budget and how that had affected local government.
The 1997 budget cuts totalled $14.7 million and in my state of New South Wales we lost $4,754,758 as a consequence. When you distribute that through local government in New South Wales it adds up to a number of services which local government has had to cut.
I believe when the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in 1997 suspended that agreement there was no formal assurance that the agreement would be reinstated and the funding base restored to an appropriate level for the 1998 budget. That was despite, even then, strong representations to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) by all the premiers of all of the states and territories. In April of this year local government was again asking us as elected representatives at a Commonwealth level to put pressure on both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to make sure that those grants were restored to their original area of priority.
What we saw then following the budget on Tuesday night was that, even though the local government financial institutions funding was restored, in real terms the fact remained that the 1997 budget had permanently cut the funding base to local government by something like $15 million per year. That has not been restored following the budget on 12 May and what that really means then is that the increase that has come to local government this year of $24 million, which I am sure the government is going to get up and crow about all over Australia, really should have been $39 million.
There should have been a commitment by this government to restore those originally suspended funding cuts to local government. Our urban areas are going to suffer from that because there is going to be continual, ongoing loss to local government and, more importantly I think, regional areas very much are going to be hard hit.
I believe that local government now Australia-wide has certainly put in measures on where they expect funding to go and also what they expect to do in their own areas. But, more importantly, in a report such as this we have the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), when he tabled the report, saying that the Commonwealth has become a major contributor to the funding of local government and is providing the expertise. We are expecting overviews and we are expecting local government to get their act together. I believe what we should be doing is honouring commitments that have come about in the past and those for the restoration of that funding suspended in 1997.
I can talk more personally of only my own areas that I represent. Not only have we had cuts in financial assistance grants and not only have we had cuts in road funding grants but we have had the absolute abolition of all flood mitigation programs. That has caused a great deal of discontent in areas such as mine. I was very pleased on Saturday when I launched the flood icon that was put together by Fairfield Council and funded by them and the state government of New South Wales. We were able to bring together an education program through the combination of a school—our Fairfield High School students—and local artists and very graphically educate people in the area about flood mitigation.
I bring that up during this local government report because I am very concerned that we have now had not only general cuts not restored in the 1998 budget but we have had no flood mitigation money restored in the 1998 budget. It means areas like mine are going to be grappling with great difficulty in trying to fund what should have been ongoing programs to protect the community I represent. We also have a very difficult problem because flooding does not occur every day of the week and people seem to become immune to the fact that it has not occurred for quite a few years. That is why it was very important that last Saturday we were able to launch a very intensive education program but more importantly an icon that shows very descriptively how the flood levels of our area had been in the 1956, 1986 and 1988 floods.
I might add that in 1988 I had in my local area houses under two and three metres of water and something like 500 people had to be rescued. You do not think that happens in residential areas of an urban part of a local government but, believe me, it does and it has occurred on more than one occasion. That is what I am trying to bring in together. We cannot continue to expect local government to deliver its services while at the same time at a Commonwealth level we do not give them a guarantee of funding. Nor can we expect them to keep programs that are going to better the communities as a whole when we have a stop-start arrangement in regard to how funds are going to be allocated.
In the meantime, I can only say to local government, particularly the areas of Fairfield and Holroyd, to keep up the good work. Let us be assured that we are going to have some sensible application at a Commonwealth level on where local government is going to go in the future not only with the tabling of this report but also I believe from contributions from the Australian Local Government Association as well as local councils across Australia. We need to make sure that this government is kept on its toes and kept informed of the loss to the community and how much it suffers when governments do not meet their commitments.
This report will talk about efficiency in local government for the 1996-97 year. Because the minister is obligated to table reports in the House, it will probably be time to have another report tabled when we still have not finished the debate on the one before us. It is time to reiterate that we did have a commitment on flood mitigation programs, from Commonwealth, state and local government, when that commitment was a two to one ratio. Certainly it was something that all governments at the time were very proud of.
The Howard government abolished that urban flood mitigation program in 1996. I was hoping it would have been reinstated in 1997 and it was not. A certain amount of money was given out when cheques went missing and then came into the throw again for a very few councils in New South Wales. I think the member for Page (Mr Causley) had a small contribution made in 1996 and, because of the outcry of the state government at the time, they realised that they had to at least make contributions to a number of metropolitan councils who were well ahead in the allocation of priorities in that flood mitigation program. My council of Fairfield, in particular, got something like $700,000.
When you make contributions on a two to one basis, for every $2 it is spending the Commonwealth is getting $5 worth of work done in that community and the people overall are gaining from that type of contribution. Yet we have seen that excellent program scrapped. In my area it is going to mean that something like $33 million is still outstanding on flood mitigation works and that is in about today's dollars. Council had a program and an estimate of completing all their flood mitigation works over the next 15 years. That is certainly going to go on a lot further now. They will not be able to meet anywhere near that target.
It worries me because populations change, particularly in urban areas. People move in. We have not had a major flood there since 1988. When people have moved in they have become very blase about it. They say, `It can't happen. It won't affect me.' I can tell you it does affect people. During the last flood, we even had the Hume Highway closed off for something like two or three days. If not for the tremendous effort at local level with the state emergency services, we could have lost lives.
I appeal again to the Commonwealth government that, if you want value in programs, you have to look at involving all levels of government, particularly when you are thinking about the programs that local government becomes very much involved in and becomes very efficient in implementing on the ground. If we look at microeconomic reforms, and at the contribution that local government makes, we have to take that into account.
Another area that also worries me, as far as local government is concerned—and I probably will not have time to bring it up during this debate with the report now being tabled—is where we are going to go with the so-called tax package of the Commonwealth government. Local government has also become very aware that a GST could be on the cards for them. They are going to be suffering enormously if a GST is introduced. Some of the surveys that they have done estimate it is going to cost local government millions and billions of dollars if the type 
 of GST that is being talked about is introduced in this tax package, whenever it sees the light of day.
I would appeal that consideration be given to all of these authorities who are expected to implement certain policies that we direct at a Commonwealth level. They are expected more and more to implement them without the means or the funding with which to do it. As you know, in New South Wales we do have rate pegging. It is something that I have always supported over a long period of time, even though councils object to it and feel that they do not adequately have the means to move their programs around to meet circumstances as they come forward. When one looks at the differentiation between one council and another, and how they move their rates about, perhaps that is something that we have to have in circumstances where better estimation of budgets has to come about.
This report talks about particularly reform. I want to talk about more than just reform. I want commitment. I want commitment given through the Commonwealth through their budget and through the states through their budgets, so that the local authority can implement their programs. We always have that cliche that local governments are closest to the people. I can assure the Commonwealth members that they are. You only have to have your local residents come in at times to complain that the garbage is not picked up or of other things that are happening. People are aware of lack of services but, more importantly, they are aware that the Commonwealth government has reneged on its funding.(Time expired)

name: Filing, Paul, MP
text:
—I am grateful for the opportunity to finally speak on this report.
—How many times have you rehearsed this speech?
—I do not need to rehearse speeches because I speak from the heart, as the member for Fisher knows, and on behalf of my constituents.
—Order! I would ask the honourable member to direct his remarks through the chair.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am always prepared to represent my constituents in a sincere and efficient manner without fear or favour, and, for that matter, without the fear of the party whip interfering with me, because I am an Independent. I am grateful for this opportunity.
In this report, parliament recognises the legitimate roles of local government in the areas of service delivery and various other functions to which it is suited. These are crucial functions, as the third tier of government in our system—that of local shires and city councils—is essential in the provision of basic services, ranging from waste management through to planning approvals, to health and cultural services, and to roads and infrastructure work. Local government is also important in its complementary function in conjunction with state and federal services. Without healthy, properly representative and accountable local government, our overall system of government is significantly weakened.
This brings me to the state of my own local government authority, the city of Wanneroo. Members in this place will remember that, in the past, I have stood as a strong critic of corruption in the city of Wanneroo. My efforts in part forced the state government to open an inquiry, and later a royal commission, into what was known as Wanneroo Inc. As a result of the inquiries, one-time Liberal mayor Wayne Bradshaw has been imprisoned, and former perjured Liberal state member Wayde Smith is now in jail.
Accusations went deeper, however, and the then Attorney-General and her husband were alleged to have strong links to the group of people that control the Liberal Party in the district that supported and nurtured the control that Mayor Bradshaw had over the city council. They were later cleared of wrongdoing within the terms of the reference of the royal commission.
Although the matters relating to Wanneroo Inc. took place well before the last federal election, its effects continue to be felt. I believe that my stand against corruption in this matter in the northern suburbs, and the subsequent loss of tens of thousands of dollars of illegal fundraising, were an important feature of my not being endorsed as the Liberal candidate for Moore in 1996.
In 1997 and 1998, with the royal commission as a catalyst, the state coalition government decided to suspend all of the democratically elected councillors in Wanneroo and subsequently to split the council into the city of Joondalup and the shire of Wanneroo. The suspension of the councillors beggars belief. The state coalition government actually used the pretence that things had not changed since the days of Bradshaw in order to justify their actions. But the reality is that three former councillors from those days sit on the state government's benches. In other words, three of the people from the days of Wayne Bradshaw's term of office, or from the period when Wayne Bradshaw had strong influence in the city of Wanneroo, now sit on state government benches, deemed to be above suspicion—while councillors who were not even in office during the Wanneroo Inc. days have been suspended.
In fact, the only three councillors who remain from those days and have thus now been punished were in fact whistleblowers. They were people who went to make complaints against what they thought was wrongdoing in the local government authority. What kind of message is that? A cynic could be excused for thinking that they were being punished for blowing the whistle on a very cosy arrangement in the northern suburbs, an arrangement that suited the former mayor, Wayne Bradshaw, very well indeed.
The suspension of councillors allowed the state government to go ahead with its plan to split Wanneroo without serious coordinated opposition from them. The way that it has been done makes it look like a serious misuse of political power by the state government in order to achieve its ends more easily. Whether this is the case is difficult to say: throughout the process, the state government has provided scant detail on why it was necessary to split the city of Wanneroo.
This is made more difficult to understand when one knows that the same state government has made a detailed exploration of amalgamating cities and shires elsewhere, as in the case of Albany in the south-west. Their rationale is to achieve economies of scale that will significantly enhance efficiency and improve services to ratepayers there. The process mirrors a long and substantial process undertaken by the Victorian government. The member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe), who is present today, will of course know about that process, whereby a number of small shires and councils have been amalgamated in order to achieve efficient operations in the third tier of government in that state.
What then is the rationale for splitting Wanneroo, which has achieved a range of efficiencies and economies by virtue of its size and corporate knowledge? Not only can it deliver services at reasonable levels of rates and charges but it also has successfully operated substantial business activity on behalf of its ratepayers, in order to subsidise its services without recourse to significant increases in rates and charges.
The neighbouring city of Stirling, also earmarked for being broken down, commissioned an independent review of the effects of a split. This showed an estimated increase in running costs, owing to losses in economy of scale, of $16 million or 22.78 per cent per year. In the current climate, this will only be offset by increased rates, reduced scope of services to residents, improvements in productivity and increased charges for use of facilities and services.
Importantly, the state government has not indicated what it believes will be the real effect on the residents of Wanneroo—
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

name: Tanner, Lindsay, MP
text:
—On Monday I am visiting the electorate of McMillan to talk about road funding issues and I would like to make some reference to one particular issue that is of considerable importance in the electorate of McMillan. Before so doing, I would like to make some comments on the context, particularly in the light of the budget of a couple of days ago.
National highway funding in Australia in the 1995 budget—the last Labor budget—was $834 million. In last year's budget that went down to $697 million. In the budget two days ago, for 1998-99, it was again slashed, to $675 million. So we have had a drop, within the space of three budgets, from $834 million to $675 million. It is also important to acknowledge that, on the basis of the government's own figures, over four years funding for the national highway maintenance program, which is roughly half of the total, is going to be reduced by half. That will obviously cause severe problems down the track for the national highway in many parts of Australia.
It is also important, as a matter of context, to point out that funding for Victoria as a proportion of total federal road funding has diminished considerably since Labor lost office. Throughout the 1990s when Labor was in office, the average percentage of total federal road funding that went to Victoria was between 20 and 21 per cent. However, that dropped to below 16 per cent last year. That percentage can be contrasted with the 22 per cent of total roadways which are in Victoria and the 25 per cent of total fuel excise receipts which Victoria contributes to the Commonwealth.
The specific matter that I wish to raise today concerns the Pakenham bypass. This is a part of the Princes Highway which I know very well for two reasons. Firstly, having lived in Orbost in my early life, I travelled many times through this particular part of what is now the outer suburbs of Melbourne. Secondly, and more particularly, I know the area well because my mother lives in Berwick and has done so for some time and so I have cause to travel in this area quite a bit now.
The road is one of the heaviest parts of the Princes Highway in terms of traffic. It currently has about 26,000 vehicles per day and it is estimated that by the year 2010 it will have about 
 37,000 vehicle movements per day. It is one of the critical growth areas of the greater Melbourne area and it currently suffers from a very high accident rate.
On 9 December 1997 the mayor, Councillor Edwin Hume, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) with respect to the Pakenham bypass, seeking road funding for that project, and I have a copy of the letter here with me today. I should add that Councillor Hume is the Mayor of the Cardinia Shire which has the greatest interest in this bypass proposal. Unfortunately, it took the Prime Minister four months to organise any response to his letter. Finally, on 3 April this year his parliamentary secretary, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), wrote back stating amongst other things `the delay in replying is regretted' and stating that the Pakenham bypass is a Victorian government responsibility.
It is interesting to note that the government was refusing to provide any roads of national importance funding for the Pakenham bypass yet it seems able to provide roads of national importance funding—it has announced that it will—for Main Road 92 in New South Wales in the marginal coalition electorate of Gilmore, and parts of that road currently are gravel.
We have therefore a situation where the government seems unable to provide roads of national importance funding for a road which currently has 26,000 cars and trucks per day, and it is anticipated that within barely a decade it will have 37,000 vehicles a day, but it can provide funding for a relatively minor road, parts of which are only gravel at the moment, because it happens to be in an electorate where the Prime Minister obviously wants to assist the cause of the incumbent member.
What does this tell us about the member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent)? Obviously, he is not a very good lobbyist for his electorate. Obviously, he does not have the ear of the Prime Minister. He does not have the ability to get the Prime Minister to respond to the needs of his electorate. He could not get an answer out of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister took four months to even respond to the correspondence. And whereas the Prime Minister is prepared to provide funding for a relatively minor road in the electorate of Gilmore, he seems unable to do that for the member for McMillan in what is obviously a very important case, the Pakenham bypass.

name: Latham, Mark, MP
text:
asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 October 1997:
(1) Has a Prime Minister of Australia written to a Premier of New South Wales concerning the nomination of the Sydney Opera House for inscription on the World Heritage list; if so, when.
(2) Has a Premier of New South Wales written to a Prime Minister of Australia concerning such a nomination; if so, when.

name: Howard, John, MP
text:
—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon Bob Carr MP, on 19 August 1996 concerning nomination of the Sydney Opera House in its Harbour Setting for inscription on the World Heritage List.
(2) The Premier of New South Wales wrote to the Prime Minister on the same topic on 24 October 1996 and 27 March 1997. The then Acting Premier, the Hon Andrew Refshauge MLA, also wrote to the Prime Minister on the topic on 25 July 1996.
